issues.title: Ed25519 compatibility
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
Beyond ristretto255, we should describe how to instantiate FROST with the [edwards25519 curve from RFC 8032](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8032#section-5.1). We might include the EdDSA verification procedure, too, listed below (bugs are my own):

~~~
EdDSA_verify(msg, sig, PK)

Inputs:
- msg, message signed, an octet string
- sig, message signature, a tuple of scalars (z, c)
- PK, EdDSA public key

Outputs: 1 if the signature is valid, and 0 otherwise

def EdDSA_verify(msg, sig, PK):
  (z, c) = SIG
  R' = (z * P) + (PK * c^-1)
  c' = Hash(m, R')
  if c == c':
    return 1
  return 0
~~~

issues.title: Drop SUM/PROD notation in favor of subroutines
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
We use SUM/PROD for convenience, but I find it to be somewhat unreadable in text form. For example, this:

~~~
f_zero = SUM(points[0], points[t]){point}: point[1] * derive_lagrange_coefficient(point[0], L)
~~~

Could be written as:

~~~
f_zero = F(0)
for point in points:
   f_zero = f_zero + (point[1] * derive_lagrange_coefficient(point[0], L))
~~~

This is certainly subjective, but I find the latter easier to read in text form. (It would be lovely if we could throw \sum and \prod in specs!)

issues.title: Review length of messages
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body: There is currently a limit on the length of messages at `2^16-1`. Let's review this restriction to determine if this length is sufficient, and what to recommend in the setting if longer messages are needed.

issues.title: Review naming of nonces
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body: Right now we refer to the nonce pair as `(D, E)` as is done in the FROST paper. Let's review this notation and decide if we should adopt more descriptive naming such as "hiding" and "binding."

issues.title: Review inputs to frost_sign
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body: Should we rewrite inputs as a function of the SigningPackage, or have SigningPackage deserialization done externally to these functions?

issues.title: Messages should be fixed size when hashing
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body:
This comes from an audit of FROST implementations, an easy fix for this is to hash the message before it is hashed to derive `rho` or the challenge. 

See recommendation 2.2 https://github.com/ZcashFoundation/redjubjub/blob/main/zcash-frost-audit-report-20210323.pdf

issues.title: Denote when and which information needs to be deleted
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body: At various times throughout the protocol, secret information should be securely deleted. We should denote in the draft when these occur and over which information.

issues.title: Add failure case when signers receive insufficient information for a valid signing operation
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body:
For example, if signers receive fewer than `t` commitments, they should abort signing. 

We should discuss also if signers were to receive commitments where either value is null.

issues.title: Signing participants should verify message before signing
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body: The draft assumes that all participants verify the message that they are signing before they sign it. We should make this assumption explicit in the draft.

issues.title: Specify consistent error codes
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body:
We should add a section with consistent error codes and a description of the errors that they correspond to, such as: 

1. When a signature share is invalid
2. When `t` is set to `1`
3. When `t` is greater than `n`
4. When fewer than `t` commitments are received
5. When any received commitment is null
6. When a participant index is `0`
7. When the message that is requested to be signed is invalid
8. When a signing request is made with respect to commitments that were used for a previous signature (i.e, request for a nonce reuse)

issues.title: Test Vectors
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body:
Here are the test vectors that we would like for each ciphersuite:

- Success case
1. (2,3), where the threshold is 2 and number of participants are 3
2. Inputs should be deterministic, outputs should be the defined serialized structs. 
3. Tests should validate for the (2,3) signers and (3,3) signers

- Failure cases: 
1. Participant index of 0
2. When t is one

issues.body: "c" and "rho" are both the result of hash-to-scalar (H2), but we don't really make clear how the scalar conversion is done.

pulls.title: Specify FROST efficiency improvements
pulls.author: chelseakomlo
pulls.body: Efficiency improvements to FROST were presented in https://eprint.iacr.org/2021/1375. This change ensures that rho is derived correctly, and cites this paper for reference.

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: Addresses issue #21

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: I don't see how this is more efficient. If anything, it seems to be less efficient since it requires more cycles to compute `binding_factor`. Was there more to be done in this PR? Also, the build breaks, which we should fix before merging.

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: Sorry, I should have been more clear in the comment. The binding factor *must* include the identifiers of all the participants. I could have included these in the `B` term, but since we already defined `L`, I thought it would be clearer to include `L` separately. Let me know which you prefer.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
> The binding factor must include the identifiers of all the participants. I could have included these in the B term, but since we already defined L, I thought it would be clearer to include L separately. Let me know which you prefer.

The change is fine, but I'm just not seeing how this adds any efficiency improvement. To try and be a bit more clear: are the changes from Schnorr21 going to land in this PR, or another one?

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: I just made the title more clear- these efficiency improvements are from Schnorr21; FROST20 requires computing different binding factors for each participant.

```suggestion
 -  ins: C. A. Wood
    name: Christopher A. Wood
```

comments.body:
@chris-wood where should I put this:

```
x9.62:
    title: "Public Key Cryptography for the Financial Services Industry: the Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA)"
    date: Sep, 1998
    seriesinfo:
      "ANSI": X9.62-1998
    author:
      -
        org: ANSI

```

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
@dconnolly there's a section up at the top we need to add, so it'd look like so:

```
normative:
   x9.62:
     title: "Public Key Cryptography for the Financial Services Industry: the Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA)"
     date: Sep, 1998
     seriesinfo:
       "ANSI": X9.62-1998
     author:
       -
         org: ANSI

informative:
   FROST20:
   ...
```

```suggestion
## FROST(P-256, SHA-256)
```

```suggestion
- Hash: SHA-256, and Nh = 32.
```

```suggestion
The value of the contextString parameter is "FROST-RISTRETTO255-SHA512".
```

reviews.body: This text looks good, though I wonder if we need to expand on the requirements for the broadcast channel? In particular, this is written such that it assumes the broadcast channel (obviously) delivers each message correctly, but I don't think we state that explicitly? (We can do this in a future PR so as to not block this.)
